item.title: Only Congress can take Dubs' Super 8s clash out of HQ - RTÉ News
item.description:
Only Congress can take Dubs' Super 8s clash out of HQ  RTÉ News

It's up to other counties to bring a motion to Congress to decide if Dublin should be afforded two games at Croke Park in the 'Super 8s', according to the GAA's ...

item.title: Colm Keys: 'Dubs' biggest problem is finding land, not players' - Independent.ie
item.description:
Colm Keys: 'Dubs' biggest problem is finding land, not players'  Independent.ie

Every year around this time John Costello's annual report to the Dublin convention drops with the usual mix of humorous barbs, sideswipes at the county's critics ...

item.title: John Costello mocks suggestion Dublin’s success has been paid for - The Irish Times
item.description:
John Costello mocks suggestion Dublin’s success has been paid for  The Irish Times

Dublin GAA's chief executive fears new rules may become detrimental to the game.

item.description:
Kilmacud Crokes vs Portlaoise: LIVE  Dublin Live

Today's Leinster SFC semi-final at Parnell Park sees Kilmacud Crokes aiming for a Leinster SFC Final as they take on Portlaoise. Throw-in is at 2pm. Crokes ...

item.description:
Dublin look set for more home comforts in Super 8s  RTÉ News

It is expected that Dublin will again have two games at Croke Park if, as expected, they reach next summer's 'Super 8s' All-Ireland quarter-final phase, according ...

item.title: Dubs go global as Ciaran Kilkenny pops up on a billboard in India - Dublin Live
item.description:
Dubs go global as Ciaran Kilkenny pops up on a billboard in India  Dublin Live

The Indian state of Karnataka would hardly be first on your list of traditional GAA hotbeds - but it seems one surgeon in the region has taken a likening to the ...

item.title: Watch: Ecstatic Kids Train with All Blacks and Dublin GAA in Croke Park - Pundit Arena
item.description:
Watch: Ecstatic Kids Train with All Blacks and Dublin GAA in Croke Park  Pundit Arena

There aren't many who can say they've had the chance train in Croke Park. Even fewer can say they've done it alongside Dublin GAA and the All Blacks.

item.title: Dublin GAA club pleads for immediate help to tackle crack cocaine crisis that is affecting kids as young as 13 - Irish Mirror
item.description:
Dublin GAA club pleads for immediate help to tackle crack cocaine crisis that is affecting kids as young as 13  Irish Mirror

Children as young as 13 are being groomed by criminal groups in Ballymun.

item.title: Cooper warns of dangers involved in 'plaudits and records' for Dubs - Independent.ie
item.description:
Cooper warns of dangers involved in 'plaudits and records' for Dubs  Independent.ie

Jonny Cooper admits he hears it all when it comes to the discourse around his Dublin team. They'll start chasing history in a few weeks' time when they look to become the first team to win Sam Maguire five times in a row, but this week Dublin GAA CEO John Costello took aim at some of Jim Gavin's side's detractors. "Words such as 'robots', 'automatons', 'emotionless' were used, by a small group of commentators, to describe our management and players on several occasions this summer," Costello wrote in his annual report while he also insisted that "the subject of Dublin's games development gr...

item.title: Dublin star Jonny Cooper says football rules overhaul unnecessary - Irish Examiner
item.description:
Dublin star Jonny Cooper says football rules overhaul unnecessary  Irish Examiner

Five-time All-Ireland winner Jonny Cooper has revealed he thinks Gaelic football is fine as it is and doesn’t require any playing rules overhaul. The experienced Dublin defender said he isn’t in favour of any of the five experimental rules which will come under a microscope from tomorrow when the O’Byrne Cup begins. Three games will be played tomorrow in Leinster’s pre-season competition and the initial plan is that the rules will remain on trial for around 160 more matches until the end of the National League. Cooper expressed his fears about spending ‘14 or 15 weeks doing something and th...

item.title: No 'microchips' or 'wires' discovered - Dublin chief responds to critics of All-Ireland winners - The42
item.description:
No 'microchips' or 'wires' discovered - Dublin chief responds to critics of All-Ireland winners  The42

DUBLIN GAA CHIEF John Costello has launched a typically robust defence of the achievements of their all-conquering senior footballers and management in his annual report that has been released today. Costello criticised pundits who have described Dublin’s players as ‘robots’ or ‘automatons’. The 2018 season saw Dublin once again sweep up a collection of honours as they won the All-Ireland, Leinster and league crowns. “Some of the commentary on our senior footballers and management was eye-catching and I think it would be remiss of me not to let it pass unchallenged,” wrote Dublin secretary ...

item.title: Throwing barbs and ties: John Costello’s sermon from the mount - Irish Examiner
item.description:
Throwing barbs and ties: John Costello’s sermon from the mount  Irish Examiner

The headlines are no surprise, even if the targets are becoming predictable. Dublin GAA secretary John Costello published his annual report yesterday and, as expected, it was a wide-ranging treatise, a little like the confirmation sermons of Bishop Connie Lucey in Cork long ago, which tended to roam among, and cover, the pressing social issues of the day. Costello’s report, as expected, left stud-marks on the shins of those who begrudge Dublin their dominance of Gaelic football. “Some of the commentary on our senior footballers and management was eye-catching and I think it would be remiss ...

item.title: Con O’Callaghan 'Everyone will be trying to stop you — that’s the reality of it’ - Irish Examiner
item.description:
Con O’Callaghan 'Everyone will be trying to stop you — that’s the reality of it’  Irish Examiner

Con O’Callaghan knows what he’s missing. That doesn’t soften the blow but spreading himself thin or leaving Jim Gavin is not on the agenda. For four years, he enjoyed the management of Mattie Kenny, which saw Cuala become the most dominant hurling club in the land. Now that the Galway man is in charge of the Dublin senior team, he’s expecting more success. Con O’Callaghan with Lucy Silke from Lucan, left, and Sophie Lawlor from Templeogue, during the Dublin squad’s visit to Our Lady’s Children’s Hospital in Crumlin after this year’s All-Ireland SFC final win over Tyrone at Croke Park. Pictu...

item.title: Joe Brolly: 'A world where Derry never won the All-Ireland is a world I want no part of' - Independent.ie
item.description:
Joe Brolly: 'A world where Derry never won the All-Ireland is a world I want no part of'  Independent.ie

It is perhaps the most famous goal in the history of Gaelic football. It is July 6, 1991. The third replay of the Leinster Championship match between Meath and Dublin is in injury-time, there are 90 seconds to go, and Meath are trailing by three points, 0-15 to 1-9. The roar from the crowd, transfixed after three epic draws in the previous month, is deafening. David Beggy wins the ball out near the middle of the field on the left touchline. "It's still possible," says Ger Canning, as Beggy handpasses it to Kevin Foley, racing through from wing-back. (Handpass number 1.) "Foley to Gillick," ...

item.title: Sinéad Aherne named Player of the Year as Dubs scoop seven LGFA All-Stars - The42
item.description:
Sinéad Aherne named Player of the Year as Dubs scoop seven LGFA All-Stars  The42

ALL-IRELAND CHAMPIONS Dublin scooped seven All-Stars, and captain Sinéad Aherne was named Senior Players’ Player of the Year, at the annual LGFA awards banquet in Dublin last night. Aherne — who was also named an All-Star for a brilliant seventh time — collected the top individual prize ahead of team-mate Lyndsey Davey and Cork captain Ciara O’Sullivan. Dubs stopper Ciara Trant was named as the All-Star goalkeeper while in the half-back line, Sinéad Goldrick won her sixth All-Star. There was a first award for Lauren Magee in midfield while 2017 Player of the Year Noelle Healy joined Davey a...

item.title: Former Tipperary minor manager appointed to succeed Mattie Kenny as Cuala boss - Independent.ie
item.description:
Former Tipperary minor manager appointed to succeed Mattie Kenny as Cuala boss  Independent.ie

Willie Maher has been appointed as the new Cuala hurling manager, succeeding Mattie Kenny in the role. Kenny led the Dublin club to back-to-back All-Ireland titles in 2017 and 2018, before stepping down last month to replace Pat Gilroy as the Dublin senior hurling manager. Maher previously managed the Tipperary minor team to All-Ireland glory in 2012 and was also a coach with the Tipperary U21 team that won the All-Ireland in 2010. He had been tipped as a possible candidate for the Tipp senior vacancy earlier this year until Liam Sheedy was appointed following the departure of Michael Ryan....

item.title: 'We've lost the likes of Ian Madigan, Ian McKinley, Scott Penny and Eoin Barr' - The42
item.description:
'We've lost the likes of Ian Madigan, Ian McKinley, Scott Penny and Eoin Barr'  The42

Kevin O’Brien reports from Parnell Park LAST SUNDAY WAS the latest chapter in Pat Burke’s eventful football career. The 35-year-old corner-forward scored three points, two from play, as Kilmacud Crokes squeezed past Portlaoise and into the Leinster club SFC final. It’ll be his fourth provincial decider with Kilmacud, but this one at the twilight of his career is as welcome as it is unexpected. “It’s been eight years,” Burke says. “I thought the chance would come for Kilmacud, I doubted that it would come for me personally. I think they were trying to retire me for a couple of years. On a pe...

item.title: Conal Keaney focused on Ballyboden’s adventure - Irish Examiner
item.description:
Conal Keaney focused on Ballyboden’s adventure  Irish Examiner

Conal Keaney has yet to confirm whether he will give another year to the Dublin hurlers, but the veteran Ballyboden St Enda’s man knows that he is just one iffy club performance away from plenty of others trying to make that call for him. Now 36, Keaney called time on his Dublin hurling career in 2016 before returning to the squad under Pat Gilroy at the start of this year. With Mattie Kenny taking over from Gilroy this season there is more than the one known unknown. Kenny has left the Ballyboden contingent to their own devices as they prepare for Sunday’s AIB Leinster Club SHC final again...

item.title: One for everyone in the audience: RTÉ reveal 26-athlete longlist for Sportsperson of the Year - Independent.ie
item.description:
One for everyone in the audience: RTÉ reveal 26-athlete longlist for Sportsperson of the Year  Independent.ie

RTÉ have named 26 athletes in the longlist for their 2018 Sportsperson of the Year award. A wide variety of sports are represented, from Ireland rugby star Johnny Sexton to rowing world champion Sanita Puspure. Last year's winner was Ireland football international James McClean. Among the favourites for the award, as well as the aforementioned duo, are boxing world champion Kellie Harrington, European bronze medalist Thomas Barr and two-belt world champion Katie Taylor. RTÉ will narrow down the longlist to 13 before announcing the winner live on RTÉ One on Saturday 15 December at 9.20pm. He...

item.title: Continuity is key as top two secure services of their exceptional managers once again - The42
item.description:
Continuity is key as top two secure services of their exceptional managers once again  The42

WHILE THE SPOTLIGHT has been on one big management job across the length and breadth of the country this week, it’s been a busy one in terms of another sport too. The big one is of course Martin O’Neill’s successor as manager of the Republic of Ireland soccer team, but there’s also been plenty of news of the ladies football managerial front. This year’s All-Ireland finalists Dublin and Cork both confirmed their respective managers for 2019, with Mick Bohan and Ephie Fitzgerald staying on for more. No changing of the guard with the top two, the continuity is definitely pleasing. Looking firs...

item.title: Paul Ryan: ‘Hurling talent’ Colm Basquel to stick with Dublin footballers - Irish Examiner
item.description:
Paul Ryan: ‘Hurling talent’ Colm Basquel to stick with Dublin footballers  Irish Examiner

By Paul Keane Dublin hurler Paul Ryan has described Ballyboden club colleague Colm Basquel as a hurling star in the making, but acknowledged it’s highly unlikely he’ll play for the county. Paul Ryan of Ballyboden St Enda's takes a late free during the AIB Leinster GAA Hurling Senior Club Championship semi-final match between Ballyboden St Enda's and Coolderry at Parnell Park, in Dublin. Photo by Sam Barnes/Sportsfile Instead, the expectation is that the speedy forward, 22, who struck a magnificent 3-3 on his full senior club hurling debut on Sunday in the AIB Leinster championship, will con...

item.title: Massive potential in new Kerry set-up, insists Burns - Independent.ie
item.description:
Massive potential in new Kerry set-up, insists Burns  Independent.ie

Whatever happens in Sunday's Munster Club SFC final, Micheál Burns will likely be running straight through to a new season with Kerry. In the space of four days, the soccer team played two scoreless draws with Northern Ireland and Denmark, scarcely getting a shot on target on either night in performances that have been met with general pessimism. The international team is, it seems, at its lowest ebb for some time and the governing body has had criticism levelled at it for not doing enough to avert that slide. In contrast, Joe Schmidt's team did what they did on Saturday night as rugby sign...

item.title: Mick Bohan ratified as Dubs boss for two more years - RTÉ News
item.description:
Mick Bohan ratified as Dubs boss for two more years  RTÉ News

Mick Bohan has been ratified as the Dublin lades football manager for two more years. Having steered the Dubs to back-to-back All-Ireland titles, Bohan will lead the side into 2019 looking to keep the silver flowing. He was a man in demand having enjoyed terrific success with the Blues Sisters. Bohan previously served time on Jim Gavin's coaching staff and helped Colm Collins' Clare to the All-Ireland SFC quarter-finals in 2016. This is is second stint with the Dublin ladies; he previously took the reins back in 2003. A statement from Dublin LGFA read: "Mick Bohan was last night reappointed...

item.title: 'I would have laughed if someone told me we'd win all this in 2018' - Independent.ie
item.description:
'I would have laughed if someone told me we'd win all this in 2018'  Independent.ie

First, the Rugby Writers of Ireland; next, the world? In the space of four days, the soccer team played two scoreless draws with Northern Ireland and Denmark, scarcely getting a shot on target on either night in performances that have been met with general pessimism. The international team is, it seems, at its lowest ebb for some time and the governing body has had criticism levelled at it for not doing enough to avert that slide. In contrast, Joe Schmidt's team did what they did on Saturday night as rugby signed off on its most successful year that yielded only a third ever Grand Slam, a r...

item.title: Pat Spillane picks his top 30 gaelic footballers of 2018 and 14 players from his 2017 selection are missing - Independent.ie
item.description:
Pat Spillane picks his top 30 gaelic footballers of 2018 and 14 players from his 2017 selection are missing  Independent.ie

I am going into full Larry Gogan mode and selecting my Top 30 – my best 30 footballers in Ireland from the 2018 Championship. This is my second time to do the list and I accept that people will have other ideas – just look at the mess the 17 All-Star selectors made of the football team. Two final thoughts on that team before it is consigned to history. Supporters of Rory Beggan have been pouring out loads of statistics about how impressive their man was. To them I offer Mark Twain’s ‘lies, damn lies and statistics’. Yes, Stephen Cluxton made a mistake or two this year, but Beggan made three...

item.title: Doherty paints stark picture of confusion over tactics among Ireland players - Independent.ie
item.description:
Doherty paints stark picture of confusion over tactics among Ireland players  Independent.ie

Matt Doherty has opened up on the confusion that Martin O'Neill's approach to preparation and team selection caused in the Ireland dressing room. In the space of four days, the soccer team played two scoreless draws with Northern Ireland and Denmark, scarcely getting a shot on target on either night in performances that have been met with general pessimism. The international team is, it seems, at its lowest ebb for some time and the governing body has had criticism levelled at it for not doing enough to avert that slide. In contrast, Joe Schmidt's team did what they did on Saturday night as...

item.title: Elusive Burke continues to punch above weight - Independent.ie
item.description:
Elusive Burke continues to punch above weight  Independent.ie

It's fair to say that Ian Burke isn't your typical modern-day footballer. Small in stature, he gives the impression that a stiff breeze would blow him over but looks can be are very deceiving and his explosive performances for Galway last summer lit up a drab championship. Described by one Twitter fan as "Galway's version of Messi", the pint-sized Burke terrorised a series of defenders with his unique X-factor en route to a first All-Star award. The 25-year-old isn't conventional in terms of appearance when compared to most footballers these days, but he also doesn't play like your average ...

item.title: Dublin star Ciarán Kilkenny seems surprised to be the face of a billboard campaign in India - Independent.ie
item.description:
Dublin star Ciarán Kilkenny seems surprised to be the face of a billboard campaign in India  Independent.ie

Dublin footballer Ciarán Kilkenny is the face of an advertising campaign for a surgeon specialising in sports injuries in India. The 25-year-old posted a image on Twitter of a large billboard that's being displayed in the Asian country to promote the practice of Dr Vivek S. Patil at Suchirayu Hospital. The ad reads: "Take a step towards a normal life with less pain and more mobility." The five-time All-Ireland winner tweeted: "Woke up this morning to this! Great to see Gaelic games being promoted in India. I hear Dr Vivek big Dubs fan" Woke up this morning to this! Great to see @officialgaa...

item.title: Rock keeps eye in with help of Sexton's kicking guru - Independent.ie
item.description:
Rock keeps eye in with help of Sexton's kicking guru  Independent.ie

Dean Rock had more than a passing interest in the AIG skills challenge that saw a handful of Dublin players take a selection of All Blacks in Dublin on Tuesday night. The Dubs and New Zealand share a major sponsor but Rock also has a keen interest in rugby. He played in his school days with CUS in Dublin's city centre and plans on heading to the Aviva Stadium on Saturday night to watch the world's top two ranked sides go head to head, where'll he'll also keep a close eye out for the fortunes of Johnny Sexton. Over the course of the past couple of years, the pair have struck up a friendship....

item.title: O'Donnell: Dubs hurling boss wants to win things now - not down the road - Independent.ie
item.description:
O'Donnell: Dubs hurling boss wants to win things now - not down the road  Independent.ie

When Eoghan O'Donnell and the rest of the Dublin hurling panel gather this Saturday, it will be the official start of the Whitehall man's sixth season in the senior set-up. It will also be the fourth manager the 23-year-old will have played under. Mattie Kenny's appointment filled the hole left by Pat Gilroy's departure. The shock of his exit took time to sink in. At first he thought he was the victim of a prank, then he and a few others tried to see if there was a way to work around Gilroy's professional commitments. When he finally accepted that Gilroy was gone, he momentarily lost his ap...

item.title: Power ranking the 12 teams left in All-Ireland club football - SportsJOE.ie
item.description:
Power ranking the 12 teams left in All-Ireland club football  SportsJOE.ie

And then there were 12. The club football championships are passing us by like a train and we're down to the provincial semis and the finals now. Everybody's saying it's a two horse race between Dr Crokes and Corofin but teams like Kilmacud Crokes will have a thing or two to say about that. Here's our ranking of the 12 teams still standing. 12 ire g Carlow Showed they weren't in Leinster just to make up the numbers by beating Newtown Blues against the odds last time out. Carlow football is rising but the semi will be an ask too demanding. Exiting at: Leinster semi-final loss to St Columba's...

item.title: Big switch! Ex-Mayo ladies football boss named new Dublin camogie manager - The42
item.description:
Big switch! Ex-Mayo ladies football boss named new Dublin camogie manager  The42

FORMER MAYO LADIES football manager Frank Browne has been appointed as the new Dublin camogie boss. Browne, who steered the Westerners to the All-Ireland final in 2017, will take the reins from five-time All-Ireland winning goalkeeper David Herity. The Kilkenny man resigned from the position in September and has since been confirmed as Kildare’s new hurling manager. Wexford native Browne has been out of inter-county management since stepping away from the Mayo helm after three years in charge last October. He was linked with the Galway camogie side shortly afterwards but nothing came of tha...

item.title: Former Mayo ladies football manager takes over Dublin camogie team - Irish Examiner
item.description:
Former Mayo ladies football manager takes over Dublin camogie team  Irish Examiner

Frank Browne has been named as the new Dublin Senior Camogie manager. The Wexford-native takes charge of the Dubs after spells with Mayo and Roscommon. He also managed the Mayo Senior Ladies football team, guiding them to the 2017 All-Ireland final. "The Dublin Camogie Board are delighted to announce the appointment of Frank Browne as the new Senior Camogie Manager for 2019," said a statement. "Frank brings with him a proven track record with senior Inter County squads in both Hurling & Ladies Football. "He managed the Mayo Senior Ladies football team and took them to an All Ireland Final i...

item.title: Mattie Kenny handed three-year term as new Dublin manager - Irish Examiner
item.description:
Mattie Kenny handed three-year term as new Dublin manager  Irish Examiner

Cuala’s two-time All-Ireland winning manager Mattie Kenny has taken over from Pat Gilroy as Dublin senior hurling boss. Following interviews late last week, the county selection committee opted for the Tynagh-Abbey Duniry man to fill the position vacated by Gilroy after one season due to work commitments. Kenny had been in the running for the role last year before Gilroy was appointed. Having guided Cuala to a second successive Tommy Moore Cup last March, Kenny was handed a three-year term on Saturday and is expected to have fellow Galway and Dublin men in his management team. Kenny is beli...

item.title: Cuala's Mattie Kenny set to be named Dublin senior hurling manager - Irish Examiner
item.description:
Cuala's Mattie Kenny set to be named Dublin senior hurling manager  Irish Examiner

Cuala's two-time All-Ireland winning manager Mattie Kenny is set to be announced as the new Dublin senior hurling boss, the Irish Examiner understands. The former Galway selector, who guided Cuala to a second consecutive All-Ireland senior club title earlier this year, had put his name forward for the role last year before Pat Gilroy was appointed. However, Kenny's superb work with the Dalkey side has now convinced the Dublin County Board that he is the man for the position. Outgoing coach Anthony Cunningham was also said to be in the shake-up but Kenny, who was his selector when Galway rea...

item.title: Paul Mannion continues to torch club defences with another impressive scoring tally - SportsJOE.ie
item.description:
Paul Mannion continues to torch club defences with another impressive scoring tally  SportsJOE.ie

Kilmacud Crokes are into the Leinster club championship semi-final and Paul Mannion was the inspiration. Crokes did for St Jude's in the Dublin SFC final recently and Mannion scored 1-6 to spur his side on. Against St Pete's, Dunboyne - the Meath champions - he outdid that scoring return. Mannion was a marked man - sometimes double-marked - for long periods but it is hard to keep him quiet for long. His blistering pace, nifty footwork and attacking awareness are all too good to keep him out of the picture for long. Against Dunboyne, he was happy to chip away with well-taken points or draw t...

item.title: Mattie Kenny succeeds Pat Gilroy as Dublin hurling boss and is given a three-year term - Independent.ie
item.description:
Mattie Kenny succeeds Pat Gilroy as Dublin hurling boss and is given a three-year term  Independent.ie

Mattie Kenny has been named as the new manager of the Dublin hurlers and has been handed a three-year term. It had been anticipated that an announcement would be made earlier this week although it is understood that the sub-committee charged with making the appointment were still deliberating over their options. In the wake of Pat Gilroy’s surprise resignation, prompted by overseas work commitments, the search for a successor was soon distilled down to three candidates: current Kilmacud manager Anthony Daly, Cuala’s double All-Ireland winner Mattie Kenny and Anthony Cunningham, who was part...

item.title: Clonkill's Leinster clash with Ballyboden to go ahead after agreement from family of tragic Annabel Loughlin - Independent.ie
item.description:
Clonkill's Leinster clash with Ballyboden to go ahead after agreement from family of tragic Annabel Loughlin  Independent.ie

IN the greater scheme of things, sport is a wonderfully inconsequential diversion from the intrusions of real life. That old truism will carry huge poignancy in Parnell Park tonight (8pm) for the refixed AIB Leinster club SHC quarter-final between Dublin champions Ballyboden St Enda's and their Westmeath counterparts from Clonkill. But for the tragic accident that befell three-year-old Annabel Loughlin, daughter of former Westmeath hurler Enda, this match would have taken place on Sunday; the winners would have moved on while the losers reflected on a season that still delivered local glory...

item.title: Jim Gavin and Andy McEntee have been very receptive to Sean Cox challenge match - SportsJOE.ie
item.description:
Jim Gavin and Andy McEntee have been very receptive to Sean Cox challenge match  SportsJOE.ie

Dublin football manager Jim Gavin and Meath counterpart Andy McEntee have both been very receptive to a challenge match between their respective sides in aide of Sean Cox. Dublin will play Meath in a challenge match provisionally set for 1:30pm on December 16 with all proceeds going towards former Dunboyne GAA chairman Sean Cox, who continues to recover from an assault suffered in Liverpool in April. A ladies match between both counties had also been reported as a potential curtain raiser, however, Dunboyne GAA have said that that match cannot be confirmed at this stage. Cox was originally ...

item.title: Fenton and Lynch take top individual awards - Independent.ie
item.description:
Fenton and Lynch take top individual awards  Independent.ie

Dublin footballer Brian Fenton and Limerick hurler Cian Lynch picked up the individual PwC GAA/GPA Player of the Year awards last night as All-Ireland hurling champions Limerick took six All-Star awards. With all three initial nominations going to Dublin footballers - Ciaran Kilkenny and Jack McCaffrey were also in the mix - the All-Ireland football champions take back the prestigious award after it had gone to Mayo players, Lee Keegan (2016), Andy Moran (2017), over the last two years. McCaffrey won it in 2015 while Fenton had a strong chance in 2016 too but this time the players' choice w...

item.title: The key statistics that support Rory Beggan's All-Star win over Stephen Cluxton - SportsJOE.ie
item.description:
The key statistics that support Rory Beggan's All-Star win over Stephen Cluxton  SportsJOE.ie

Monaghan goalkeeper Rory Beggan won his first All Star award last week after a fantastic year with the Farney County. Beggan ousted both Dublin goalkeeper Stephen Cluxton and Laois shotstopper Graham Brody to win the award. Cluxton captained Dublin to their fourth consecutive All-Ireland title in September but he has not won an All-Star award since the 2013 season where he guided the Jacks to a win over Mayo for what was his second Celtic Cross. Former Dublin midfielder Ciaran Whelan believes that his omissions stem from his frosty relationship with the media while five-time All-Ireland win...

item.title: Dublin appoint new senior hurling manager - SportsJOE.ie
item.description:
Dublin appoint new senior hurling manager  SportsJOE.ie

Cuala manager Mattie Kenny has been appointed as Dublin's new senior hurling manager. Kenny will take over from former manager Pat Gilroy who resigned from the role in September citing work commitments and overseas travel. Kenny and his backroom team will be ratified by the Dublin county board at their next official meeting. Mattie Kenny has been appointed Senior Hurling Manager for a three year term. The management team will be confirmed at the next meeting of the County Committee #GAA — Dublin GAA (@DubGAAOfficial) November 3, 2018 Gilroy said upon his resignation: "It was a huge honour f...

item.title: Football All-Stars debate, Mayo trials, London champion Liam Gavaghan interview - The GAA Hour - JOE.ie
item.description:
Football All-Stars debate, Mayo trials, London champion Liam Gavaghan interview - The GAA Hour  JOE.ie

Colm Parkinson is joined with Conán Doherty and Conor Henegan to discuss the official GAA football All-Stars and how Paul Mannion's place at wing forward has affected the rest of the team. Tir Chonaill Gaels captain Liam Gavaghan speaks from London and a whole weekend preview.

item.title: Eight Dubs make Alan Brogan's football All Stars team - Independent.ie
item.description:
Eight Dubs make Alan Brogan's football All Stars team  Independent.ie

Alan Brogan picks his football All Star team. STEPHEN CLUXTON (Dublin) Leadership and nerveless execution make Cluxton the most important player of the modern era. Amazingly without an All Star since 2013, when Dublin were four points down in the final against Tyrone and under pressure for the first time this year, he once again produced the kick-outs to steady the ship. EOGHAN BÁN GALLAGHER (Donegal) A modern-day corner back with a keen eye for attack, Gallagher scored a great goal in the Ulster final against Fermanagh. He was consistently a real driving force from the Donegal full-back li...

item.title: 7 Dublin stars feature on 2018 All-Star football team - The42
item.description:
7 Dublin stars feature on 2018 All-Star football team  The42

ALL-IRELAND CHAMPIONS Dublin have a total of seven players on the 2018 PwC All-Star football team. Jim Gavin’s side earned a convincing 2-17 to 1-15 victory over Tyrone in this year’s All-Ireland final, winning their fourth title in succession, and several players have been recognised as a result of that feat. Meanwhile, the other counties represented are Monaghan (3), Tyrone (2), Kerry, Galway and Donegal (all 1). This year’s developments mean Dublin are now second in the all-time list of All-Star winners with 123 behind Kerry (141). GAA President John Horan chaired a selection committee ...

item.title: Rory Beggan pays fitting tribute to Stephen Cluxton - SportsJOE.ie
item.description:
Rory Beggan pays fitting tribute to Stephen Cluxton  SportsJOE.ie

Monaghan goalkeeper and 2018 All Star Rory Beggan has hailed Dublin goalkeeper Stephen Cluxton as the benchmark for all other goalkeepers in gaelic football. Beggan won his first All Star award on Thursday after a fantastic season with Monaghan edging out fellow nominees Cluxton and Laois goalkeeper Graham Brody to claim the honour. Cluxton captained Dublin to a fourth successive All-Ireland win in Septemberwith a comprehensive win over Tyrone but he has not won an All Star since his first Sam Maguire win with the Jacks in 2016. Despite another year on the outer, Beggan still holds the Parn...

item.title: Open Thread: We've picked our 2018 All-Star football team but what's your prediction? - The42
item.description:
Open Thread: We've picked our 2018 All-Star football team but what's your prediction?  The42

WE’VE BEEN GAZING into our crystal ball ahead of the announcement of the 2018 PwC All-Star football team tomorrow morning. You can find the full list of nominations here. Eight players from All-Ireland champions Dublin make our team, with two from finalists Tyrone and semi-finalists Monaghan, and one apiece from Donegal, Galway and Kerry. Monaghan goalkeeper Rory Beggan and Galway forward Damien Comer may feel hardest done by in our selections, but they were edged out by Stephen Cluxton and Shane Walsh respectively. Don’t agree with our team? Of course you don’t! Then head straight to the c...

item.title: 'Sam Maguire needs a minder abroad' - legendary cup spat into by pranksters - Independent.ie
item.description:
'Sam Maguire needs a minder abroad' - legendary cup spat into by pranksters  Independent.ie

Former GAA president Seán Kelly has said that teams should appoint one individual to look after the Sam Maguire Cup when they take it abroad. Mr Kelly was speaking after an incident last weekend when a group of pranksters stole and subsequently spat into the trophy following a Dublin GAA night out in New York. Another man was seen posing with the Sam Maguire on his crotch as he lay on the floor in a leaked WhatsApp video. The cup was taken to the Mean Fiddler Bar and Grill in Manhattan but was then reportedly removed from the bar. The New York Police Department said it had not received a cr...

item.title: Dublin hoping to unveil new hurling boss next week - Independent.ie
item.description:
Dublin hoping to unveil new hurling boss next week  Independent.ie

DUBLIN GAA chiefs are confident they’ll have a new hurling manager installed in the next week. County board chairman Seán Shanley accepted the urgency of the situation, with Dublin opening their Walsh Cup campaign in Carlow on December 9, just over six weeks away. However, he also made clear that the search to finalise a replacement for Pat Gilroy is well advanced. “Hopefully next week we will have it all sorted before the following weekend,” Shanley told The Herald. In the wake of Gilroy’s surprise resignation, prompted by overseas work commitments, the search for a successor was soon dist...

item.title: 'Basically, it’s the wrong decision' - Tomás Ó Sé hits out at Stephen Cluxton's All Star snub - Independent.ie
item.description:
'Basically, it’s the wrong decision' - Tomás Ó Sé hits out at Stephen Cluxton's All Star snub  Independent.ie

Kerry legend Tomás ó Sé believes Stephen Cluxton is a victim of his own success after he was once again overlooked for an All-Star award. Cluxton has been honoured five times by All-Star selectors but missed out on the 2018 award after the committee plumped for Monaghan's Rory Beggan ahead of the Parnells man. It was the third year in a row Cluxton had been nominated only to miss out after Mayo's David Clarke picked up the 2016 and 2017 awards. And ó Sé insists it was the "wrong decision". "Basically, it's the wrong decision," the Irish Independent columnist said. "You'll have arguments abo...

item.title: Stephen Cluxton is the best ever, he just wasn't the best this year - SportsJOE.ie
item.description:
Stephen Cluxton is the best ever, he just wasn't the best this year  SportsJOE.ie

Outrage, total outrage... The 2018 Gaelic football All-Stars select has been announced and there is some cause for concern. Stephen Cluxton has been snubbed for the fifth year in a row. Since his last All-Star win, he has lifted Sam Maguire four times. The man has captained the All-Ireland winners five times in total, and to put that into context; only two men have lifted the Sam Maguire cup on three occasions, the last of those in 1917. - John Kennedy (1891, 1892 & 1894) - Sean O'Kennedy (1915,1916,1917) His record is incredible, and it probably won't ever be replicated.The 37-year-old has...

item.title: A night behind the goals Paul Mannion was shooting into - SportsJOE.ie
item.description:
A night behind the goals Paul Mannion was shooting into  SportsJOE.ie

Just when you think you have him, he's already gone. And you'll never make that mistake again because it's always worth Paul Mannion's while. He took seven shots on Monday night, scored 1-6. If you let that stat sink in for a second it's the only one you need to know from the Dublin senior football final where Paul Mannion must have given one of the best full forward performances Parnell Park has been lucky enough to witness and where the Jude's defenders must have been wondering what in the name of God they had done to deserve this. He was that good. Each one of their full back line tried ...

item.title: Official 2018 All-Star team: 7 Dublin, 2 Tyrone, 1 Galway, 1 Donegal - SportsJOE.ie
item.description:
Official 2018 All-Star team: 7 Dublin, 2 Tyrone, 1 Galway, 1 Donegal  SportsJOE.ie

The official2018 PwC Football All-Star award winners have been announced. Seven Dublin players were honoured with Brian Howard receiving his first gong in this his debut season with the All-Ireland champions. David Clifford, Karl O'Connell, Padraig Hampsey and Rory Began join Howard in the first-timers list whilst Corofin's untouchable full forward Ian Burke is the bolder on the line-up as he takes a well-deserved spot at 15 after a superb season with the semi-finalists. Jonny Cooper collects his second award alongside Colm Cavanagh who has been named at full back. Ryan McHugh, meanwhile, t...

item.title: Sam Maguire cup back with Dublin football team after going missing in New York - Irish Examiner
item.description:
Sam Maguire cup back with Dublin football team after going missing in New York  Irish Examiner

The GAA is set to launch an investigation after the Sam Maguire cup went missing during a Dublin tour of New York this weekend. It has been reported that the famous trophy vanished from the Mean Fiddler Bar and Grill, an Irish bar in Manhattan. Members of the All Ireland winning Dublin team had been attending a function at the bar. [readmore]881461[/readmore] Footage obtained by the Sunday World shows fans posing with Sam in a New York hotel room, with the paper reporting that the video and images appeared online. One picture shows a man spitting into the cup, while another man appears in a...

item.title: Mannion masterclass the difference as Kilmacud Crokes power past St Jude's to win Dublin championship - Independent.ie
item.description:
Mannion masterclass the difference as Kilmacud Crokes power past St Jude's to win Dublin championship  Independent.ie

Paul Mannion delivered a tour de force in Parnell Park this evening as Kilmacud Crokes ended an eight-year wait for a Dublin SFC title. It was their first since 2010, ending their longest spell without one since their first in 1992. Mannion lit up the crisp night with the simplicity of his play, nailing four points within the first 21 minutes, each one showing similar style and composure as he turned with scarcely a glance to convert. By the end, the had scored 1-6 and St Jude's, who had knocked out Ballymun Kickhams and St Vincent's, had no answer to his brilliance. Crokes' powerful runnin...

item.title: Paul Mannion shows he's one of the best with 1-6 from play en route to county title - SportsJOE.ie
item.description:
Paul Mannion shows he's one of the best with 1-6 from play en route to county title  SportsJOE.ie

Dublin SFC final Kilmacud Crokes 2-12 St. Jude's 0-13 The Dublin championship on October nights really shows off the best players in the country. Anyone lucky enough to have ever witnessed Diarmuid Connolly under the Parnell lights with a St. Vincent's jersey on will have seen some magic conjured and they'd have seen first-hand the very real distance between him and the rest - the laypeople. The same goes for a lot of those Dublin superstars. The Dublin championship is absolute quality but we're talking about one of the greatest teams of all time and their main men are going to stand out. I...

item.title: A small club offering a snapshot of modern Dublin GAA - RTÉ News
item.description:
A small club offering a snapshot of modern Dublin GAA  RTÉ News

The big show in Dublin on Monday is the Senior Football Championship final at Parnell Park, with a capacity crowd expected and TG4’s cameras in place. The match between Killmacud Crokes and St Jude’s will feature All-Ireland winners and All-Stars; some of the best players in the game currently. Hopes are high for a high quality contest. Normally the curtain-raiser on these big days is the county minor final, featuring the next generation of stars, or maybe the junior or intermediate deciders. This October bank holiday weekend though, Dublin GAA have decided to spread their net a little wide...

item.title: LIVE: St Jude's v Kilmacud Crokes, Dublin senior football championship final - TheJournal.ie
item.description:
LIVE: St Jude's v Kilmacud Crokes, Dublin senior football championship final  TheJournal.ie

Join us for live minute-by-minute updates as St Jude’s and Kilmacud Crokes do battle in the Parnell Park decider.

item.title: On the cusp of greatness after modest beginnings - Independent.ie
item.description:
On the cusp of greatness after modest beginnings  Independent.ie

In 1978 Fr John Greene stood at the altar in St Jude's Parish Church in Templeogue and announced to the congregation that a committee had been formed and a GAA club was going to be set up in the community. It was a welcome development for the blossoming area. Templeogue was a newly built suburb in south Dublin. And while there was a school, church and shop there was no centre for Gaelic games, so a group in the parish decided to rectify that - and St Jude's GAA club was born. "It was a new parish, there was a mix of Dublin people and a large amount of country people moving into the area and...

item.title: Dublin heartbreak again for Kilmacud as 'Boden win - RTÉ News
item.description:
Dublin heartbreak again for Kilmacud as 'Boden win  RTÉ News

Ballyboden St Enda's 2-15 Kilmacud Crokes 1-15 Dublin footballer Colm Basquel came off the bench at Parnell Park to help steer Ballyboden St Enda's to the county Senior Hurling Championship title. Joe Fortune's side trailed Anthony Daly's Crokes at half-time but dominated the second-half of this replay and held firm late on to claim a first title since 2013. Just a point separated the south-side rivals in this replay encounter entering injury-time but a Paul Ryan point, bringing his tally to 1-05, and a Basquel insurance score sealed it. It's Crokes' third year in-a-row to lose a county fin...

item.title: Former Dub Guckian leaves door the open on possible Leitrim switch - Independent.ie
item.description:
Former Dub Guckian leaves door the open on possible Leitrim switch  Independent.ie

Like his club St Jude's in Dublin, Chris Guckian has been knocking on the door long enough. The southside outfit are back in their first county senior final since 2009, having contested four semi-final in the last five years, while Guckian himself might turn his attention to playing county football himself next year. Guckian has been in and around Dublin set-ups for a few seasons now. He's won a National League medal but never made the breakthrough at championship. "In and out, a bit of training when Pillar was around, Gilroy, and then I had two league campaigns with the Dubs under Gavin," ...

item.title: Daly stands on brink of further capital success with Crokes - Independent.ie
item.description:
Daly stands on brink of further capital success with Crokes  Independent.ie

To those on the outside, Anthony Daly's decision to venture into club management and take the reins with Kilmacud Crokes might have been seen as somewhat left-field. Making a 500km round-trip from his base in Clarecastle to Stillorgan through Dublin's rush-hour traffic is no easy task but part of the former Dubs boss will always remain in the capital, particularly on the south side. Numerous medal presentations in Crokes down through the years - including their triumphant 2012 SHC-winning squad - as well as the Dublin launch of his autobiography in their clubhouse left him with an "affinity...

item.title: McCarthy eyes capital gains after club success - RTÉ News
item.description:
McCarthy eyes capital gains after club success  RTÉ News

Winning a first senior club camogie title with her club has only fueled Faye McCarthy's belief that Dublin can now achieve top-flight success at inter-county level. On Sunday last, the St Judes custodian was part of the side that defeated Na Fianna after extra-time. Next up is a date with Kilkenny's Thomastown in the Leinster semi-final on Sunday next. Speaking at an event to mark AIB's continued sponsorship of the GAA and Camogie championships, McCarthy reflected on what she described as a "huge" win for the club based in Templeogue. "It was a big achievement for the female team to win the...

item.title: Dalo talks managing Kilmacud, Sheedy's return in Tipp and Keaney's leadership - The42
item.description:
Dalo talks managing Kilmacud, Sheedy's return in Tipp and Keaney's leadership  The42

ON SUNDAY, ANTHONY Daly will lead Kilmacud Crokes in the Dublin SHC final against Ballyboden St Enda’s. Their stunning semi-final win to dump out reigning champions Cuala means they’re narrow favourites to take the crown this time around. The Clare native has previously enjoyed major success in the capital, having led Dublin to Leinster and National League wins in the past. Kilmacud are chasing their first county title since 2014, after losing the 2016 and 2017 finals to eventual Leinster and All-Ireland champions Cuala. When they won the championship in 2012, incidentally was the man who p...

item.title: Lambert eager to get back into Dubs team next season - Independent.ie
item.description:
Lambert eager to get back into Dubs team next season  Independent.ie

Simon Lambert is busy preparing for Sunday's Dublin SHC championship clash against Kilmacud Crokes but the Ballyboden St Enda's man has a dual purpose this weekend as he is gunning for a return to the county panel for 2019. Lambert was axed from the Dublin squad for the 2016 season by then manager Ger Cunningham and later described the reasons as "disrespectful" at a fractious time for hurling in the capital. However, he is hoping to catch the attention of the new manager - who is set to be unveiled next week - in Sunday's showdown with the Stillorgan men. "Yeah, I'm 29 now, going to be 30 ...

item.title: 'If my (sub) role can push team over the line, then I'll gladly do it' - Costello - Independent.ie
item.description:
'If my (sub) role can push team over the line, then I'll gladly do it' - Costello  Independent.ie

It's not inconceivable to say that if Cormac Costello hailed from any other county outside of Dublin, he would have been a regular starter in attack every season since leaving the minor ranks in 2012. As evidenced by his match-winning cameo when firing three points as Mayo hearts were broken late on in the 2016 All-Ireland SFC replay, Costello looked destined for greatness. Much has happened in the meantime and his transition into the Dublin starting 15 hasn't materialised with a series of injuries - he tore his hamstring three times in 2017 - derailing his progression. Amazingly, Costello ...

item.title: TG4 with two LIVE club finals this weekend - SportsJOE.ie
item.description:
TG4 with two LIVE club finals this weekend  SportsJOE.ie

Two live games. It's not ideal for the players but it suits TG4 just fine. The Dublin senior football final between Kilmacud Crokes and St Jude's takes place on the Bank Holiday Monday evening at 5.00 and it will be shown live on Telifs na Gaeilge. Waiting around all weekend for a game on Sunday is a pain, waiting around on a Bank Holiday weekend, until the Monday - is just blackguardism of the highest order of those players. But us spectators won't complain. TG4's coverage is class. They've two club games every weekend this weather and they nearly always choose the ones with the most poten...

item.title: Galway ace Comer admits 'we didn't perform against Dubs' - Independent.ie
item.description:
Galway ace Comer admits 'we didn't perform against Dubs'  Independent.ie

Another year of the Kevin Walsh project down and more tangible progress for Galway's footballers. Since Walsh first took charge of the Tribesmen ahead of the 2015 season, they have moved through the gears and passed milestones along the way. They went from missing out on promotion from Division 2 on the final day to winning that league outright. In the process there have been back-to-back Connacht titles as well as three championship wins on the bounce over Mayo for the first time since 1984. There was also an unbeaten campaign on their return to the top flight and a championship win over K...
